idolum: <entryFree id="n21360" type="greek" key="i_do_lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">īdōlum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-on</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ei)/dwlon</foreign>. <sense id="n21360.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">an image</hi>, <hi rend="ital">form</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">a spectre</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apparition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ghost</hi>: idola atque atomos vincere Epicuri volam, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 478, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mox apparebat idolon, senex macie et squalore confectus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:27:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 27, 5</bibl></cit> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:6:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 6, 21</bibl>; Fam. 15, 16, 1 and 2, written as Greek).—</sense><sense id="n21360.1" n="II" level="1"> In the Church fathers, <hi rend="ital">an idol</hi>: idolorum cultor, Aug. in. Psa. 78, 3; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Serm. 123, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">venerator idolorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Conf. 8, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deficere a cultu idolorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Mort. Pers. 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Idol. 1 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Spect. 13</bibl> et saep.—Scanned īdŏlum, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> adv. Symm. 2, 48</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sedul.</author> 5, 146 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
idomeneus: <entryFree id="n21361" type="main" key="I_do^me^neus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Īdŏmĕneus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">quadrisyl.</orth>), <itype>ĕi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)idomeneus</foreign>, <sense id="n21361.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a king of Crete</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the leader of the Cretans against Troy</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:401" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 401</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:358" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 358</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 81" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 81</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:270" default="NO">270</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
idomenius: <entryFree id="n21362" type="main" key="Ido^me^nius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Idŏmĕnius</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n21362.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Macedonian city</hi> Idomene, <hi rend="ital">Idomenian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Idomeniosne (to be scanned as a quinquesyl.) petam montes?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 178</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
idonee: <entryFree id="n21363" type="main" key="i^do_ne^e_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĭdōnĕē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. idoneus <sense id="n21363.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
idoneitas: <entryFree id="n21364" type="main" key="i^do_ne^i^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĭdōnĕĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>idoneus</etym>, <sense id="n21364.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fitness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">meetness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">usefulness</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">servi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Serm. de Div. 106:3" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Serm. de Div. 106, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
idoneus: <entryFree id="n21365" type="main" key="i^do_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĭdōnĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. root indh-, idh-, to kindle; prop. bright, conspicuous; cf. Idus</etym>, <sense id="n21365.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fit</hi> for something (esp. for an action), <hi rend="ital">meet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">proper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">becoming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">capable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">convenient</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sufficient</hi> (of persons and things; class. and very freq. in prose and poetry; syn.: aptus, opportunus); constr. most commonly with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">qui</hi>, the <case>dat.</case>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.;</hi> less freq. with <hi rend="ital">in aliquid</hi>, the <case>abl.</case>, or the <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> </sense><sense id="n21365.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tot quidem non potuisti adducere homines magis ad hanc rem idoneos, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non essem ad ullam causam idoneus, judices, si hoc non viderem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad amicitiam esse idoneus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:17:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 17, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loco pro castris ad aciem instruendam opportuno atque idoneo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 8, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum statim auditoris animum nobis idoneum reddimus ad audiendum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 1, 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est enim (lex) ratio mensque sapientis, ad jubendum et ad deterrendum idonea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:4:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scientia opportunitatis idoneorum ad agendum temporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:40:142" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 40, 142</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad captandos lacertos tempestates non sunt idoneae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consilia idonea ad hoc nostrum negotium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 6, 1</bibl></cit> al.—</sense><sense id="n21365.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">qui</hi>, or a <hi rend="ital">rel. adverb</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">video hercle ego te me arbitrari, Euclio, hominem idoneum, Quem senecta aetate ludos facias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:2:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 2, 74</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 2, 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 4, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum ille (Pompeius) idoneus non est, qui impetret, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Imp. Pomp. 19, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tibi fortasse idoneus fuit nemo, quem imitarere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:16:section=41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 16, § 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">idonea mihi Laelii persona visa est, quae de amicitia dissereret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:1:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et rem idoneam, de qua quaeratur, et homines dignos, quibuscum disseratur, putant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nequeo mearum rerum initium ullum invenire idoneum, Unde exordiar narrare, quae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 3, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21365.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">erit alius (discipulus) historiae magis idoneus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:8:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 8, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:49" default="NO">12, 10, 49</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">idoneus arti Cuilibet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non sat idoneus Pugnae ferebaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:19:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 2, 19, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vixi puellis nuper idoneus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 26, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum idoneos rhetori pueros putaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:3:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Falernum mihi semper idoneum visum est deversorio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:19:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 19, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castris idoneum locum deligit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 10, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 35, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad cibos viribus conservandis idoneos redeunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:10:6" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 10, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(volunt poëtae) simul et jucunda et idonea dicere vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:334" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 334</bibl></cit>: metuensque futuri In pace, <cb n="IDUS" /> ut sapiens, aptarit idonea bello, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 2, 111</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut patriae sit idoneus,</quote> <trans><tr>serviceable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:71" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 71</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">dat. gerundi</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">Julius, qui perferendis militum mandatis habebatur idoneus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n21365.4" n="(d)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus (Cethegi) eloquentiae est auctor, et idoneus quidem mea sententia, Q. Ennius, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>a proper</tr>, <tr>sufficient voucher</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:15:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 15, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auctor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:20" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:4:42" default="NO">2, 4, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui si adductus gratia minus idoneum hominem praemio affecisset, etc.,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>deserving</tr>, <tr>worthy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 3, 7</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:15:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 15, 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">idoneus suae rei quisque defensor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:46" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:3:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juvenis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:5:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 5, 21</bibl></cit>: debitor, <hi rend="ital">safe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">able to pay</hi> (opp. inops), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:4:27" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 4, 27 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">tutor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:26:1:9" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 26, 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:27:8:1" default="NO">27, 8, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:35:2:88" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 35, 2, 88</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 4:39" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 4, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">servi conscii, tempus idoneum, locus opportune captus ad eam rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:24:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 24, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 18</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">lex promulgata idoneo die,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:4:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 4, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minus idoneis (verbis) uti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:34:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 34, 154</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">aptum atque idoneum verbum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:144" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 144</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vox actoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:7:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 7, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lectio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:ib. 8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8</bibl></cit> praef. § <cit><quote lang="la">28: cautio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:4:50" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 4, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paries,</quote> <trans><tr>safe</tr>, <tr>sound</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:2:36" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 39, 2, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:2:13" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 19, 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pignora,</quote> <trans><tr>sufficient</tr>, <tr>satisfactory</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:1:33" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 22, 1, 33</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">si persona idoneior accedat ad emptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:2:4:section=6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 2, 4, § 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:23:2" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 47, 23, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:29:3" default="NO">43, 29, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:50:6:5" default="NO">50, 6, 5</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Herm. 18</bibl>; Anim. 18 (al. idonior or idoneor). —<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in deligendis idoneis judicium et diligentiam adhibere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:18:62" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 18, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum idoneis collocutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:25:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 25, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullo idoneo respondente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:44" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 44</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:4:39" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 4, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">novum illud exemplum a dignis et idoneis ad indignos et non idoneos transfertur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 51, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per idoneos et secreti ejus socios,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apud idonea provinciarum,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>at proper stations</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 5</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">infirmi et in nullam spem idonei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 5:33" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 5, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">componere materias in hoc idoneas, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 15</bibl></cit>.—*（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <case>abl.</case> (like dignus): <cit><quote lang="la">res idoneas dignitate suā judicare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 3, 5</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">fons etiam rivo dare nomen idoneus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>large enough</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si torrere jecur quaeris idoneum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 4, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accendi idonea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:N. Q. 1:15:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> N. Q. 1, 15, 1</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">idoneor (late Lat.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:2:4:section=6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 2, 4, § 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:23:2" default="NO">47, 23, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Herm. 18</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Anim. 18</bibl>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ĭdōnĕē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">fitly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suitably</hi>, <hi rend="ital">properly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">duly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sufficiently</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">exordium est oratio animum auditoris idonee comparans ad reliquam dictionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:15:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 15, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ergo cavendum est idonee. Quid est idonee? Satisdato utique aut pignoribus datis,</quote> <trans><tr>enough</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:5:4" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 5, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cavere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:5:3:41" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5, 3, 41</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:27:8:1" default="NO">27, 8, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magis idonee reficere parietem,</quote> <trans><tr>more safely</tr>, <tr>solidly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:2:41" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 39, 2, 41</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">idonius,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pall. 3 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
idos: <entryFree id="n21366" type="greek" key="i_dos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">īdos</orth>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">ei)=dos</foreign>, Lat. species, <sense id="n21366.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a form</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shape</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 58:17" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 58, 17</bibl> sqq. (written sometimes as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
idulis: <entryFree id="n21367" type="gloss" key="i_du_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">īdūlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Idus</etym>, <sense id="n21367.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to the Ides</hi>: idulis ovis dicebatur, quae omnibus idibus Jovi mactabatur, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=104" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 104</bibl> Müll.; cf. Fest. S. V. SACRAM VIAM, p. 290 b <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 15</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:56" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 56</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
idumaea: <entryFree id="n21368" type="main" key="I^du_maea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĭdūmaea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)idoumai/a</foreign>, <sense id="n21368.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a region of Palestine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 14, 15, § 70</bibl>.—Called also <usg type="style">poet.</usg> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĭdūmē</orth>, <itype>es</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:12" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 216</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n21368.1" n="II" level="1"> Deriv.: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĭdūmaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Idumea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Idumean;</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> also for <hi rend="ital">Palestinian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Jewish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">palmae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">triumphi,</quote> <trans><tr>over Judea</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:2:5" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">porta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:160" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 160</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
iduo: <entryFree id="n21369" type="gloss" key="i_du^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">īdŭo</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 15, § 17</bibl>, an Etrusc. word, i. q. dividere, from the root vid; whence viduus and divido.</entryFree>
idus: <entryFree id="n21370" type="main" key="I_dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Īdus</orth> (often <orth extent="full" lang="la">eidus</orth>, v. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 42</bibl>), <itype>ŭum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 15</bibl>, from the Etrusc. ‡ iduo, to divide; hence, qs. the divided or half month; but prob. Sanscr. root, indh-, idh-, to kindle, lighten; indu, moon; prop. the days of light, of the moon</etym>, <sense id="n21370.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the three days in each month from which the other days were reckoned in the Roman calendar</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Ides; it fell upon the fifteenth day of March</hi>, <hi rend="ital">May</hi>, <hi rend="ital">July</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and October; upon the thirteenth day in the remaining months</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Kalendae, Nonae): res ante idus acta sic est: nam haec idibus mane scripsi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duas epistulas accepi postridie idus, alteram eo die datam, alteram idibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:17:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 15, 17, 1</bibl></cit>: haec S. C. <pb n="879" /> <cb n="IGIT" /> perscribuntur a. d. VIII. idus Januarias, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 5, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia licet concurrant: idus Martiae consolantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:14:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 14, 4, 2</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">stulta jam iduum Martiarum est consolatio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid vellent, a. d. idus Apr. reverterentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iduum Septembrium dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">postero iduum dierum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 26</bibl></cit>.—The ides were sacred to Jupiter, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 14</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">idulis.—Interest was paid on the ides: fenerator Alphius, Jam jam futurus rusticus, Omnem redegit idibus pecuniam, Quaerit Kalendis ponere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:2:69" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 2, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diem pecuniae Idus Novembres esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam vel sibi habeat nummos, modo numeret Idibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 20, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praetermitto ruinas fortunarum tuarum, quas omnes impendere tibi proximis Idibus senties,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 6, 14</bibl></cit>.—The payment of school-money at the ides is referred to in: <cit><quote lang="la">(pueri) Ibant octonis referentes idibus aera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 75</bibl></cit>; v. Orell. ed h. 1.</sense></entryFree>
idyia: <entryFree id="n21371" type="main" key="I^dyia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĭdyia</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)idui=a</foreign>, <sense id="n21371.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the wife of Æētes and mother of Medea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:19:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 19, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 25" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
idyllium: <entryFree id="n21372" type="main" key="I_dylli^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Īdyllĭum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ēdyllĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ei)du/llion</foreign>, <sense id="n21372.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Idyl</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pastoral poem</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:14:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 14, 9</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>, the title of a collection of little poems by Ausonius.</sense></entryFree>
ierne: <entryFree id="n21373" type="main" key="Ierne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Iernē</orth>, <itype>es</itype>, v. Hibernia.</entryFree>
iesus: <entryFree id="n21374" type="main" key="I^e_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ĭēsus</orth> (in late Lat. also dissyl.), <itype>u</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)ihsou=s</foreign>, <sense id="n21374.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Jesus Christ</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Juvenc.</author> 2, 106</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Apoth. 770 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
igilium: <entryFree id="n21375" type="main" key="Igili^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Igilĭum</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n21375.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small island in the Tyrrhene Sea</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Giglio</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:19" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:34:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 34, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Rutil.</author> 1, 305</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
igitur: <entryFree id="n21376" type="main" key="i^gi^tur"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ĭgĭtur</orth>, <sense id="n21376.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> [pronom. stem i- of is; suffix -ha (-dha); Gr. -<foreign lang="greek">qa</foreign>; Sanscr. -iha, here; -tur, = -tus (Sanscr. -tas), as in penitus, antiquitus, etc., from thence], introduces an inference or deduction, <hi rend="ital">then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">therefore</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thereupon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accordingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in these circumstances</hi> (in class. prose usu. placed after the first word of the clause; cf. below, III.; syn.: itaque, ergo; cf.: eo, ideo, idcirco, propterea; quamobrem, quare, etc.). </sense><sense id="n21376.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">SI. IN. IVS. VOCAT. NI. IT. ANTESTATOR. IGITVR EM. CAPITO, Fragm. XII. Tab.: mox magis, cum otium mihi et tibi erit, igitur tecum loquar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 2, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quando habebo, igitur rationem mearum fabricarum dabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:177" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 177</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 4, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cetera consimili mentis ratione peragrans, Invenies igitur multarum semina rerum Corpore celare, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:677" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 677</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21376.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n21376.3" n="A" level="2"> Pleon., with <hi rend="ital">tum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deinde</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">demum</hi>, <hi rend="ital">then at length</hi>, <hi rend="ital">then certainly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">then first</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi emeritum'st stipendium, igitur tum Specimen cernitur, quo eveniat aedificatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 2, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum igitur tibi aquae erit cupido,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">igitur tum accedam hunc, quando quid agam invenero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:1:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 1, 159</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">post id igitur deinde faciam palam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 1, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">miserumst opus, igitur demum fodere puteum, ubi sitis fauces tenet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 2, 1, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">igitur demum omnes scient quae facta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 2, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 1, 145</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">post igitur demum faciam ut res flat palam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">demum igitur, quom seis jam senex, tum in otium te conloces, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 3, 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21376.4" n="B" level="2"> In drawing a logical conclusion (but not with et, atque, que; v. Krebs, Antibarb. p. 540), <hi rend="ital">therefore</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accordingly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consequently: St.</hi> Ligna hic apud nos nulla sunt. <hi rend="ital">Co.</hi> Sunt asseres. <hi rend="ital">St.</hi> Sunt pol. <hi rend="ital">Co.</hi> Sunt igitur ligna, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 6, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si enim est aliquid in rerum natura, quod hominis mens, quod ratio, quod vis, quod potestas humana efficere non possit, est certe id, quod illud efficit, homine melius. Atqui res caelestes omnesque eae, quarum est ordo sempiternus, ab homine confici non possunt. Est igitur id, quo illa conficiuntur, homine melius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:6:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 6, 16</bibl></cit>: quid ergo haec ab illa conclusione differt, Si mentiris, mentiris; <cit><quote lang="la">mentiris autem, mentiris igitur?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 30, 96</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:17:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 17, 40</bibl>: quodsi melius geruntur, quae consilio, quam quae sine consilio administrantur; <cit><quote lang="la">nihil autem omnium rerum melius quam omnis mundus administratur: consilio igitur mundus administratur, Quint 5, 14, 9: quod cum ita sit, certe nec secerni nec dividi nec discerpi nec distrahi potest, ne interire quidem igitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:29:71" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 29, 71</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 34, 82</bibl>; 1, 36, 88: sequitur, ut nihil paeniteat, nihil desit, nihil obstet: ergo omnia profluenter,<cb n="IGIT" />  absolute, prospere; <cit><quote lang="la">igitur beate,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 18, 53</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">corresp. with ergo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>, and 15 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">atqui falsum quod est, id percipi non potest, ut vobismet ipsis placet. Si igitur memoria perceptarum comprehensarumque rerum est: omnia, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:33:106" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 33, 106</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21376.5" n="C" level="2"> In consecutive interrogations, <hi rend="ital">then</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolor igitur, id est summum malum, metuetur semper, etiam si non aderit: jam enim adesse poterit. Qui potest igitur habitare in beata vita summi mali metus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:28:92" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 28, 92</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">utrum igitur hactenus satis est?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:4:25" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 4, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quo igitur loco est? credo equidem in capite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:29:70" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 29, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi igitur locus fuit errori deorum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:31:76" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 31, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">possumusne igitur in Antonii latrocinio aeque esse tuti?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:12:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 12, 12, 27</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">totiesne igitur sententiam mutas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:14:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 8, 14, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cur has igitur sibi tam graves leges imposuerit, cum? etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 8, 23</bibl></cit>.—In ironical or sarcastic interrog. clauses: <cit><quote lang="la">igitur hocine est amare? arare mavelim quam sic amare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicet aliquis: Haec igitur est tua disciplina? sic tu instituis adulescentes?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:17:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 17, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 10, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">id indigne ferens ille: Hunc igitur, regem agnoscimus, inquit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:11:23" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 11, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin igitur ulciscimur Graeciam et urbi faces subdimus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:7:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 7, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:10:6:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 6, 23</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n21376.6" n="D" level="2"> In resuming an interrupted thought: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Q. Metellus L. F. causam de pecuniis repetundis diceret, ille, ille vir, cui patriae salus dulcior quam conspectus fuit, qui de civitate decedere quam de sententia maluit: hoc igitur causam dicente, cum, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 5, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:2:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:13:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 13, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:48:177 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 48, 177 al.</bibl>—Esp. after a parenthesis: recta effectio (<foreign lang="greek">kato/rqwsin</foreign> enim ita appello, quoniam rectum factum <foreign lang="greek">kato/rqwma</foreign>) recta igitur effectio crescendi accessionem nullam habet, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:14:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 14, 45</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 22, 74</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">scripsi etiam (nam etiam ab orationibus dijungo me fere, etc.) scripsi igitur Aristotelio more, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu enim sapienter (nunc demum enim rescribo iis litteris, quas mihi misisti convento Antonio Tiburi) sapienter igitur, quod manus dedisti, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rerum autem cognitiones (quas vel comprehensiones vel perceptiones appellemus licet) has igitur ipsas propter se asciscendas arbitramur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:5:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 5, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 33, 107</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 14, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 54 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:2:2" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Thras. 4, 3</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n21376.7" n="E" level="2"> In emphatically repeating a word or thought: <cit><quote lang="la">quae mihi omnia grata sunt, de L. Mescinio gratissimum ... id igitur—puto enim etiam atque etiam mihi dicendum esse—velim existimes mihi te fecisse gratissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 28</bibl></cit> a, 1: <cit><quote lang="la">ea vis, ea igitur ipsa, quae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:31:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 31, 84</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21376.8" n="F" level="1"> In returning to or summing up a preceding train of thought, <hi rend="ital">I say then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so then</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as I was saying</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in short</hi>: ut cum videmus speciem primum candoremque caeli; <cit><quote lang="la">deinde conversionis celeritatem tantam, quantam, etc.... tum vicissitudines dierum ac noctium ... tum globum terrae eminentem e mari ... tum multitudinem pecudum ... hominemque ipsum ... atque hominis utilitati agros omnes ac maria parentia: haec igitur et alia innumerabilia cum cernimus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:28:70" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 28, 70</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:11:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 11, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 1, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:25:105 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 25, 105 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n21376.9" n="G" level="1"> To introduce a special amplification of a thought previously introduced in general terms, <hi rend="ital">then</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de hominibus dici non necesse est. Tribus igitur modis video, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:20:66" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 20, 66</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:32:122" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 32, 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam pluribus modis accipi solet, non equidem in omnes eam particulas secabo, sed maxime necessarias attingam. Est igitur unum genus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:63" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut igitur ante meridiem discesserunt, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 5, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sit igitur (ut supra significavi) divisio rerum plurium in singulas, partitio singularum in partes discretus ordo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1</bibl></cit>. 1: <cit><quote lang="la">prima est igitur amplificandi vel minuendi species,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:4:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 4, 1</bibl></cit> (v. also III. A. below).—</sense><sense id="n21376.10" n="III" level="1"> Position. </sense><sense id="n21376.11" n="A" level="2"> Sometimes igitur begins a sentence (in Cic. only in sense last described, II. E. above; freq. in Sall., Tac., Curt., and Liv.; <cit><quote lang="la">v. Zumpt, Gram. § 357): nunc juris principia videamus. Igitur doctissimis viris proficisci placuit a lege, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:6:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">igitur his genus, aetas, eloquentia prope aequalia fuere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 54:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 54, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:46:3" default="NO" valid="yes">46, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:1:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 1, 1</bibl>: de quo, quia nunc primum oblatus <cb n="IGNA" /> est, pauca repetam: <cit><quote lang="la">nam et ipse pars Romanarum cladium erit. Igitur matre libertina ortus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 72</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 31</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n21376.12" n="B" level="2"> Igitur is sometimes placed after several words: <cit><quote lang="la">referamus nos igitur ad eum quem volumus incohandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:9:33" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 9, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eamne rationem igitur sequare?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:23:76" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 23, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid dicis igitur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:6:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 6, 12</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid me igitur mones?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:64:132" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 64, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paria sunt igitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:27:75" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 27, 75</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">videndum est igitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:14:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 14, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hujus quoque igitur criminis, te accusante, mentio nulla fiet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:10:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Div. in Caecil. 10, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">huic homini parcetis igitur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:32:section=81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 32, § 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in hominem dicendum est igitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 10, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hi autem non sunt: ne Nymphae quidem deae igitur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:17:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 17, 43</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in animo quidem igitur sensus remanet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:34:82" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 34, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille mihi videtur igitur vere augurari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:15:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 15, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae est melior igitur in hominum genere natura?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:14:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 14, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tibi negoti est meae domi igitur?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 63</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ignarus: <entryFree id="n21377" type="main" key="igna_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignārus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (also, ‡ ignarures <foreign lang="greek">a)gnoou=ntes</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.; v. gnarus <sense id="n21377.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi>), <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>in-gnarus, like ignavus, ignotus, from the negative in and gnavus, gnotus</etym>, <hi rend="ital">ignorant</hi> of a thing, <hi rend="ital">not knowing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unacquainted with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inexperienced</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unaware</hi> (syn.: inscius, nescius, insciens). </sense><sense id="n21377.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (freq. and class.); constr. usu. with the <hi rend="ital">gen.;</hi> less frequently with a <hi rend="ital">rel.-clause</hi>, with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> alone, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n21377.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ait se peregrinum esse, hujus ignarum oppidi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:3:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 3, 3, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imprudens harum rerum ignarusque omnium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">audi, ne te ignarum fuisse dicas meorum morum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 53</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignara artis meretriciae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 1, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratorem ne physicorum quidem esse ignarum volo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:34:119" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 34, 119</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">physicae rationis ignari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:21:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 21, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignarus si sit facundiae ac poliendae orationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:14:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 14, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicujus rei ignarus atque insolens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 48, 207</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magna pars Pisonis ignari,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>not knowing him</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 50</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">alter alterius ignarus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 30, 36, § 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignara puella mariti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 132</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">formica haud ignara ac non incauta futuri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 1, 1, 35</bibl></cit>.—Of inanim. and abstr. things: <cit><quote lang="la">qui gurges aut quae flumina lugubris Ignara belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 1, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:2:149" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 2, 149</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non ignara philosophiae grammatice,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignara hujusce doctrinae loquacitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:2:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 2, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21377.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">rel. clause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignari, quid gravitas, quid integritas ... quid denique virtus valeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:28:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 28, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:20:75" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 20, 75</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum quid ageretur in locis reliquis, essent ignari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. G. 8:43:2" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. G. 8, 43, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud ignari quanta invidiae immineret, tempestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:38:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 38, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo essent in loco ignari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21377.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quamquam non sumus ignari multos studiose contra esse dicturos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignari venisse dictatorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:36:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 36, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:22:1" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 22, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignarus, non omnes esse rogandos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 263</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non quidem sibi ignarum, posse argui quod, etc.,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>he well knew</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21377.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> alone: <cit><quote lang="la">placito ignara moveri Atropos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:67" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 67</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu me ignaro nec opinante, inscio notes et tuos et tuorum amicorum necessarios, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:16:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 16, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi imperium ad ignaros pervenit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 51, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 91:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 91, 1</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:Quint. 20:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Quint. 20, 64</bibl>: obpressit igitur necopinantes ignarosque omnes Perseus. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:57:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 57, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quis laudat Arelli Sollicitas ignarus opes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 6, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quisnam ignarum nostris deus appulit oris?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:338" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 338</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.: Ba.</hi> An nescis quae sit haec res? <hi rend="ital">Si.</hi> Juxta cum ignarissimis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 62</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n21377.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> * </sense><sense id="n21377.7" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Unmindful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">regardless of</hi> any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">o socii (neque enim ignari sumus ante malorum), O passi graviora, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 198</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21377.8" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi> (like gnarus), <hi rend="ital">not known</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unknown</hi>, = ignotus (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; <cit><quote lang="la">not in Cic.): ignarus aeque (ac nescius) utroqueversum dicitur, non tantum qui ignorat, sed et qui ignoratur. Sallustius: more humanae cupidinis ignara visundi. Vergilius (A. 10, 706),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:12:20 sq" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 12, 20 sq.</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 129, 18 sq.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mare magnum et ignara lingua commercia prohibebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 18:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 18, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus agrestis vita est, circumscriptio ignara est et fraus, Sen. de Ira, 3, 2: quem (amorem) non Fors ignara dedit, sed saeva Cupidinis ira,</quote> <trans><tr>unknown</tr>, <tr>obscure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:453" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 453</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n21377.9" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: pauci interiere: plerosque velocitas et regio hostibus ignara tutata<pb n="880" /> <cb n="IGNA" />  sunt, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 52:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 52, 4</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jamque aderat Theseus, proles ignara parenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:404" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 404</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non quidem sibi ignara, quae de Silano vulgabantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 69</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaedam (sidera) sunt aliis omnino ignarissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:14:1:13" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 14, 1, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ignave: <entryFree id="n21378" type="main" key="igna_ve_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. ignavus <sense id="n21378.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
ignavesco: <entryFree id="n21379" type="main" key="igna_vesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvesco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n21379.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> [ignavus], <hi rend="ital">to grow inactive</hi> or <hi rend="ital">slothful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">anima nec quiescit nec ignavescit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 43 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
ignavia: <entryFree id="n21380" type="main" key="igna_vi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n21380.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inactivity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">laziness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">idleness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sloth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">listlessness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cowardice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worthlessness</hi> (syn.: socordia, desidia, inertia, pigritia, segnities; opp.: fortitudo, alacritas). </sense><sense id="n21380.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">dare argentum adulescenti, qui exaedificaret suam incohatam ignaviam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 95</bibl></cit>: venit mihi ignavia; ea mihi tempestas fuit; <cit><quote lang="la">mi adventu suo grandinem imbremque attulit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 2, 57</bibl></cit> Lorenz ad loc.: <cit><quote lang="la">contraria fortitudini ignavia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:54:165" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 54, 165</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so opp. fortitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:11:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 2, 11, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inertiam, ignaviam, desidiam, luxuriam (adversariorum) proferre,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 1, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">timiditas et ignavia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:7:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 7, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignaviam suam tenebrarum ac parietum custodiis tegere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Perd. 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">socordiae sese atque ignaviae tradere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so with socordia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 58:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 58, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per luxum atque ignaviam aetatem agere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod istic (= in te) cum ignavia est scelus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:47:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 47, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae tanta animis ignavia venit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:733" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 733</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">copia (cibi) ignaviam affert,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 14, 14, § 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fumo crebriore et ignavia earum (apium) excitatur ad opera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 16, 15, § 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavia corpus hebetat, labor firmat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">ignaviam necessitas acuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:5:4:31" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 5, 4, 31</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n21380.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of things: <cit><quote lang="la">odoris,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>weakness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 25, 54, § 119</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ignavio: <entryFree id="n21381" type="hapax" key="igna_vi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvĭo</orth>, <itype>īre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n21381.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to render inactive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slothful</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">dispirited</hi>, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 123, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 126, 15</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 282 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
ignaviter: <entryFree id="n21382" type="main" key="igna_vi^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. ignavus <sense id="n21382.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
ignavus: <entryFree id="n21383" type="main" key="igna_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>in-gnavus, navus</etym>, <sense id="n21383.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">inactive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lazy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slothful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">idle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sluggish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">listless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without spirit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cowardly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dastardly</hi> (syn.: iners, socors; opp.: strenuus, alacer, fortis). </sense><sense id="n21383.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of living beings (freq. and class.): <cit><quote lang="la">homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:5:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 5, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si non fecero Ei male aliquo pacto, me esse dicito ignavissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:6:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 6, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid ergo ille ignavissumus mi latitabat?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 82</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 128</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:4:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 4, 2, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo inertior, ignavior, magis vir inter mulieres proferri non potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:78:section=192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 78, § 192</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavus miles ac timidus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:23:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 23, 54</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">compertum habeo, milites neque ex ignavo strenuum neque fortem ex timido exercitum oratione imperatoris fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 58:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 58, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">feroces et inquieti inter socios, ignavi et imbelles inter hostes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavissimus ac fugacissimus hostis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:28:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 28, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavissimi homines (opp.: fortissimi viri),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">canis Ignavus adversum lupos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:6:2" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(apes) Ignavaeque fame et contracto frigore pigrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 259</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavum, fucos, pecus a praesepibus arcent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:435" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 435</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus ignavum quod lecto gaudet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:105" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 105</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cedentibus ignavis et imbecillis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in bello poena ignavis ab imperatoribus constituitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:16:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 16, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in victoria vel ignavis gloriari licet, adversae res etiam bonos detractant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 53 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">gloriam, honorem, imperium bonus ignavus aeque sibi exoptant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 11:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 11, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">favimus ignavo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 2, 73</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n21383.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">legiones operum et laboris ignavae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 18</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">possis ignavus haberi et subiti casus improvidus, si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:272" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 272</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n21383.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n21383.4" n="A" level="2"> Of inanim. and abstr. things (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">quae vitia non sunt senectutis, sed inertis, ignavae, somniculosae senectutis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 11, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemora,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>unfruitful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:208" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 208</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">globus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>immovable</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 8, 6, § 33</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">gravitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:821" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 821</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stagna jacentis aquae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:442" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 442</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavo stupuerunt verba palato,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>speechless</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:6:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 6, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 1, 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">anni,</quote> <trans><tr>spent in idleness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 15, 1</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">otia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:7:25" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 1, 7, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">septima lux,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the Jewish Sabbath</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:106" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 106</bibl></cit>: ignavum conferunt stipendium, <hi rend="ital">only money</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not soldiers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arms</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:39:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 39, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sucus meconium vocatur, multum opio ignavior,</quote> <trans><tr>weaker</tr>, <tr>less efficacious</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:202" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 18, 76, § 202</bibl></cit>: quorundam<cb n="IGNI" />  flos tantum jucundus, reliquae partes ignavae, ut violae ac rosae, <hi rend="ital">without smell</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 7, 18, § 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cornicula ante oculos ignava,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>of no use</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 28, 34, § 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignavum est rediturae parcere vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:492" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 492</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21383.5" n="B" level="2"> Of things that produce inactivity or indolence, <hi rend="ital">that renders slothful</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inactive</hi>: nec nos impediet illa ignava ratio, quae dicitur: appellatur enim quidam a philosophis <foreign lang="greek">a)rgo\s lo/gos</foreign>, cui si pareamus, nihil omnino agamus in vita. Sic enim interrogant: <cit><quote lang="la">Si fatum tibi est, etc.... Recte genus hoc interrogationis ignavum et iners nominatum est, quod eadem ratione omnis e vita tolletur actio,</quote> <trans><tr>relaxing</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:12:28 sq" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 12, 28 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frigus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:763" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 763</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:7:529" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 529</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 18, 20, § 64</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos> in two forms, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ignāvē</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ignā-vĭter</orth>. </sense><sense id="n21383.6" n="(a)" level="5"> Ignave, <hi rend="ital">sluggishly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">slothfully</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without spirit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quid abjecte, ne quid timide, ne quid ignave, ne quid serviliter muliebriterve faciamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:23:55" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 23, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere multa,</quote> <trans><tr>flatly</tr>, <tr>tamely</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 67</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21383.7" n="(b)" level="5"> Ignaviter, <hi rend="ital">lazily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sluggishly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tardily</hi>: ignaviter quaerere, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 513, 14</bibl>; Quadrig. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1010</bibl> P.; Hirt. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 6, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n21383.8" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">carpere ignavius herbas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:465" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 465</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ignefacio: <entryFree id="n21384" type="main" key="igne^fa^ci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignĕfăcĭo</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ignis + facio</etym>, <sense id="n21384.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make fiery;</hi> only in <hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi> ignefactus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 2, 2, 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
igneolus: <entryFree id="n21385" type="main" key="igne^o^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignĕŏlus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n21385.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. dim.</hi> [igneus], <hi rend="ital">fiery</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">vigor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 3, 186</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
ignesco: <entryFree id="n21386" type="main" key="ignesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignesco</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n21386.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch. n.</hi> (in <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> ignescitur, Laber. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 481, 7</bibl>; Fragm. Com. v. 26 Rib.) [ignis], <hi rend="ital">to take fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to become inflamed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to burn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kindle</hi> (syn.: inardesco, exardesco). </sense><sense id="n21386.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: ex quo eventurum nostri putant, ut ad extremum omnis mundus ignesceret, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:46:118" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 46, 118</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lumen capere atque ignescere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:847" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 847</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21386.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of color: <cit><quote lang="la">purpura et candor et tertium ex utroque ignescens,</quote> <trans><tr>kindling</tr>, <tr>breaking into a flame</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 2, 8, § 21</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n21386.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to burn with passion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to glow</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">furiis ignescit opertis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:520" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 520</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virgo (Pallas),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:9:460" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 9, 460</bibl></cit>: pectora, Claud. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 2, 45</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Rutulo muros et castra tuenti Ignescunt irae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor menti, Col. poët. 10, 211: odia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:525" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 525</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultus sanguine,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 78</bibl></cit>.— * </sense><sense id="n21386.4" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardore pari nisuque incurrere muris Ignescunt animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:180" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 180</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
igneus: <entryFree id="n21387" type="main" key="igne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n21387.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fiery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burning-hot</hi> (cf.: fervidus, calidus). </sense><sense id="n21387.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">sidera tota esse ignea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:15:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 15, 40</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">sol,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:426" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 426</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arces (i. e. caelum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignea vis caeli,</quote> <trans><tr>ether</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: ignea vis, <hi rend="ital">fire</hi>, as one of the primary elements, acc. to Heraclitus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:14:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 14, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aetne,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:341" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 341</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Chimaera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:17:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 17, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 17, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardor,</quote> <trans><tr>of fire</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 33, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">celeritas, motus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:9:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 9, 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21387.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of color, <hi rend="ital">fiery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">flaming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">resplendent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gemmae igneo colore fulgentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 38, 57, § 137</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">purpura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:427" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 427</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cingula gemmis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12:527" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12, 527</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n21387.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">fiery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glowing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fervid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ardent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vehement</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">furor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:541" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 541</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vigor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:730" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 730</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 9, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">volat igneus aequore Tarchon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:746" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 746</bibl></cit>; cf.: igneus in pugnas, in Martem et proelia et hostem, <hi rend="ital">burning for the strife</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:209" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 209</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ignia: <entryFree id="n21388" type="gloss" key="ignia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignia</orth> <itype>vitium vasorum fictilium</itype>, Paul. ex. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=105" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 105</bibl> Müll. [perh. = <foreign lang="greek">i)/knuon</foreign>, i. e. <foreign lang="greek">ko/nion, smh=ma</foreign>, Hesych.].</entryFree>
igniarius: <entryFree id="n21389" type="main" key="igni^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ignis</etym>, <sense id="n21389.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to fire.</hi> </sense><sense id="n21389.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapis,</quote> <trans><tr>flint</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 33 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n21389.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ignĭārĭum</orth>, <itype>ĭi</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an implement for producing fire</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:207" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 40, 76, § 207</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
ignicans: <entryFree id="n21390" type="main" key="igni^cans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ignĭcans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n21390.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">flaming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fiery-colored</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">grana,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1672,001:Rer. Gest. Alex. 3:21" default="NO"><author>Jul. Val.</author> Rer. Gest. Alex. 3, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
